Latina\",\"editorialArtwork\":{\"storeFlowcase\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is3-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/2a/57/ea/2a57ea01-32d2-355f-5861-22b29663a5c3/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"fb0007\",\"textColor1\":\"0a0507\",\"textColor2\":\"120f0f\",\"textColor3\":\"2c0006\",\"textColor4\":\"350b0d\"},\"subscriptionHero\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/ef/f8/1d/eff81d99-8537-df53-cff0-3096d3911631/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"f5f5f7\",\"textColor1\":\"3c0410\",\"textColor2\":\"400b15\",\"textColor3\":\"5c2933\",\"textColor4\":\"5f2e37\"}},\"upc\":\"190296646058\",\"copyright\":\"Distributed By Warner Music Latina, ? 2021 JHRH\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1569186561\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"It can be somewhat startling to fully consider that the prolific pioneer and continuing gatekeeper of the corridos tumbados sound only recently made it out of his teens. Thus, the significance of Natanael Cano naming his latest project \u003ci\u003eA Mis 20\u003c/i\u003e should not be taken lightly given just how much he’s accomplished up to this point, and in such short order. Fans of his growing catalog will find more of his high-quality signature sound, with lyrical themes drawing from trap music, culture on both sides of the border, and his own life. Among the highlights here are “Sin Ti” and “El F,” the latter a team-up with Rancho Humilde compatriot Junior H.\",\"short\":\"The corridos tumbados king exits his teens a música Mexicana star.\"},\"isCompilation\":false},\"relationships\":{\"artists\":{\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1569186561/artists?l=en-US\",\"data\":[{\"id\":\"1406984792\",\"type\":\"artists\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/artists/1406984792?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"name\":\"Natanael Cano\",\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/natanael-cano/1406984792\",\"artwork\":{\"width\":1393,\"height\":1393,\"url\":\"https://is4-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Music115/v4/3b/17/b2/3b17b216-4b9f-c629-9b8e-fc847bdb0544/pr_source.png/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"ffffff\",\"textColor1\":\"510b15\",\"textColor2\":\"53161d\",\"textColor3\":\"743c43\",\"textColor4\":\"75454a\"},\"editorialArtwork\":{\"centeredFullscreenBackground\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":2160,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/ed/c4/29/edc429d2-044e-5c9b-37b4-d8b402810178/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"455675\",\"textColor1\":\"ffff4c\",\"textColor2\":\"fdcb35\",\"textColor3\":\"d6dc53\",\"textColor4\":\"d4b240\"},\"subscriptionHero\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features123/v4/bc/8d/0a/bc8d0ae0-8684-54b9-3e72-6f2d663a2f52/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"322315\",\"textColor1\":\"f8e5cf\",\"textColor2\":\"d2a993\",\"textColor3\":\"d0beaa\",\"textColor4\":\"b28e7a\"},\"vipSquare\":{\"width\":5120,\"height\":5120,\"url\":\"https://is3-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/8c/d7/ca/8cd7ca9a-013e-026a-7313-25d97deb9a94/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"6178a5\",\"textColor1\":\"050b19\",\"textColor2\":\"110f21\",\"textColor3\":\"151c30\",\"textColor4\":\"1e2037\"}}}}]}}},{\"id\":\"1568599593\",\"type\":\"albums\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1568599593?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"artwork\":{\"width\":3000,\"height\":3000,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Music115/v4/6c/c6/eb/6cc6eb8a-ed02-ac4e-fd37-1faf73fc0ad4/21UMGIM38975.rgb.jpg/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"8e8e8e\",\"textColor1\":\"040404\",\"textColor2\":\"070707\",\"textColor3\":\"1f1f1f\",\"textColor4\":\"222222\"},\"artistName\":\"DMX\",\"isSingle\":false,\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/album/exodus/1568599593\",\"isComplete\":true,\"genreNames\":[\"Hip-Hop/Rap\",\"Music\"],\"trackCount\":13,\"isMasteredForItunes\":true,\"releaseDate\":\"2021-05-28\",\"name\":\"Exodus\",\"artistUrl\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/dmx/135710\",\"recordLabel\":\"Def Jam Recordings\",\"editorialArtwork\":{\"storeFlowcase\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is2-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/b7/aa/fa/b7aafaad-f0cc-6bfe-23bb-c3ebccfd36c6/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"8b8b8b\",\"textColor1\":\"090909\",\"textColor2\":\"101010\",\"textColor3\":\"1d1d1d\",\"textColor4\":\"232323\"},\"subscriptionHero\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is2-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/d5/11/20/d5112018-272d-a062-f810-270d75f4f763/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"280000\",\"textColor1\":\"f2f1ed\",\"textColor2\":\"e28e3e\",\"textColor3\":\"cac1be\",\"textColor4\":\"bc7132\"},\"staticDetailSquare\":{\"width\":3840,\"height\":3840,\"url\":\"https://is3-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/34/dc/39/34dc391f-59ac-a9c8-3adf-3cbb05697231/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"595859\",\"textColor1\":\"e7d9e7\",\"textColor2\":\"dbd1e6\",\"textColor3\":\"c8bdc8\",\"textColor4\":\"bfb7c7\"}},\"upc\":\"00602438263226\",\"copyright\":\"? 2021 Def Jam Recordings, a division of UMG Recordings, Inc.\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1568599593\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"The posthumous album is a tough thing to get right. If nothing else, it can be hard for fans to ascertain what’s really representative of an artist’s vision versus what was completed after death to the sometimes less than exacting specifications of the stewards of said estate. In the case of dearly departed hip-hop legend DMX, however, the Dog-loving faithful had nothing to worry about. “All of the songs was finished,” longtime friend, collaborator, and executive producer of his \u003ci\u003eExodus\u003c/i\u003e album Swizz Beatz tells Apple Music. “This album was done while he was living. I know they’re saying ‘the album after he's gone,’ but really he did the album before he was gone.” \u003cbr /\u003e\\nPop Smoke was initially slated to appear on “Money Money Money,” but a leak forced Swizz to switch up the plan and bring on Moneybagg Yo. Otherwise, though, \u003ci\u003eExodus\u003c/i\u003e is exactly how X designed it—one of hip-hop’s most impactful MCs making space for the voices he revered, while staying true to a career-long practice of baring his soul on record. “He gave people real shit,” Swizz says. “He gave you a front-row seat into his life, because he loved his fans, he loved his people, and it's where he was at. He was comfortable, and I think that every artist should get to that level one day, to where they’re not capping and they’re saying real things that are happening in their life and that they’re going through. And it should be uncut, like Dog did on this record.” Below, Swizz talks us through—track by track—the last musical testament of friend and icon DMX.\u003cbr /\u003e \\n\u003cb\u003e“That’s My Dog” (feat. The LOX \u0026 Swizz Beatz)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Setting the tone was very important. This is a real curated body of work, and me and X hadn't been in the studio like this for 12 years. The first rapper you hear on the album is Jadakiss, so that's letting you know the tone right there for where we going. This is not play-around.”\u003cbr /\u003e \\n\u003cb\u003e“Bath Salts” (feat. JAY-Z \u0026 Nas)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Out the gate, we just wanted to put pressure on everybody—and then take them on this journey at the same time. With Hov and Nas, people know what they getting, you know what I’m saying?” \u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Dogs Out” (feat. Lil Wayne \u0026 Swizz Beatz)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Wayne always spoke highly of X—when he was living \u003ci\u003eand\u003c/i\u003e when he passed. If you go and you look at YouTube, you see Wayne bringing out X at [Miami Beach nightclub] LIV. His concert I was at, he did a whole tribute about X. They went crazy [here].”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Money Money Money” (feat. Moneybagg Yo)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I didn't want the album just to be artists from when X first came out. I wanted it—and he wanted it—to be energy from today, which is why Pop Smoke originally had this slot. I actually made the beat for Pop Smoke. Pop Smoke was like, 'I want something that sound like X.' And then I think by mistake or whatever, the verses got out, and they was put on different songs, so we had to change it at the last minute. The song is called 'Money Money Money,' so I felt like Moneybagg Yo was perfect for it, and I actually like him as an artist. The beat reminded me of 'Stop Being Greedy' a little bit when I was doing it. It put me in that old X vibe.”\u003cbr /\u003e \\n\u003cb\u003e“Hold Me Down” (feat. Alicia Keys)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“‘Hold Me Down’ is one of my favorite records, not only because of my wife on it, but because the way that DMX opens up about his life. If you listen to the record, he starts off, ‘I'm pulled in opposite directions, my life's in conflict/That’s why I spit words that depict a convict.’ And to have a simple chorus that's just saying, 'Hold me down'—’cause that's all X wanted. He wanted the people that loved him to hold him down. That's what he cared about.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Skyscrapers” (feat. Bono)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Bono is like family to me, and I had [an early version of the track]. I asked for his permission to give it to my brother because I felt that he deserved it more, especially with the body of work that we was working on. As soon as X heard it, he automatically went in. And then it was crazy, ’cause Bono was writing him saying, ‘Man, it's an honor to have my voice next to yours.’ He drew him a drawing and wrote X a poem and everything right before he passed. It was pretty deep.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Stick Up Skit” (feat. Cross, Infrared \u0026 Icepick)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This is the late, great Icepick Jay, who passed away [in 2017]. He did all the skits, so that was kind of like paying homage. It just fit, and we can't have an album with no skits.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Hood Blues” (feat. Westside Gunn, Benny the Butcher \u0026 Conway the Machine)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“[Griselda and DMX], they was both fans of each other. X liked them cause they was super hard. And they was a fan of X, so that was pretty easy. X kind of did this one on his own, to be honest. I just sent the beat and they did they thing.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Take Control” (feat. Snoop Dogg)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“[Snoop and DMX], they knew they wanted to do something after Verzuz. We did the song and it was like, ‘Yo, you know what? Snoop would sound good on this.’ That’s Marvin Gaye and that's 'Sexual Healing,' so you know we had to do the right thing. I love that record. It shows you the 'How's It Goin' Down' vibe.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Walking in the Rain” (feat. Nas, Exodus Simmons \u0026 Denaun)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“[DMX’s son] Exodus was in the studio with us for a lot of [the album]. He was loving ‘Walking in the Rain’ and he just started singing it and he was on beat and everything. It was a beautiful sight to see.\\\"\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Letter to My Son (Call Your Father)” (feat. Usher \u0026 Brian King Joseph)\u003c/b\u003e\\n“[DMX] pulled me in the corner and was like, ‘I'm going to let you hear this.’ I kept it acoustic so you could hear every word, and then felt like it needed something else. Then Usher came into the studio and did what he did to it. I left it to where the music had some space for people to reflect instead of it being a whole bunch of words, ’cause X didn't put a whole bunch of words on a record. He said what he said. And it was beautiful.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Prayer”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This was live at Kanye's Sunday Service. It was his latest prayer. That's why we put that one on there. He did another one where he was rapping, but this one feels more like what it should be. He was the master of prayers, for sure.”\",\"short\":\"Swizz Beatz on DMX’s final album: “He gave you a front-row seat into his life.”\"},\"isCompilation\":false,\"contentRating\":\"explicit\"},\"relationships\":{\"artists\":{\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1568599593/artists?l=en-US\",\"data\":[{\"id\":\"135710\",\"type\":\"artists\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/artists/135710?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"name\":\"DMX\",\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/dmx/135710\",\"artwork\":{\"width\":2400,\"height\":2400,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features124/v4/a9/be/2b/a9be2ba2-0532-76af-f79c-72bb374331fb/mza_18072070992083116527.png/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"eff1f0\",\"textColor1\":\"030302\",\"textColor2\":\"17120d\",\"textColor3\":\"323232\",\"textColor4\":\"423e3b\"},\"editorialArtwork\":{\"storeFlowcase\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is2-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/91/b8/2f/91b82f52-0bd2-cb0e-ffc0-5b024ab1334f/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"000000\",\"textColor1\":\"efefef\",\"textColor2\":\"d1d1d1\",\"textColor3\":\"bfbfbf\",\"textColor4\":\"a7a7a7\"}}}}]}}},{\"id\":\"1556687227\",\"type\":\"albums\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1556687227?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"artwork\":{\"width\":3000,\"height\":3000,\"url\":\"https://is2-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Music114/v4/d1/47/d3/d147d396-afd8-c1e5-774e-11ab92d67c18/20UM1IM08220.rgb.jpg/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"c4d7f5\",\"textColor1\":\"15243a\",\"textColor2\":\"0f2843\",\"textColor3\":\"38485f\",\"textColor4\":\"334b66\"},\"artistName\":\"easy life\",\"isSingle\":false,\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/album/lifes-a-beach/1556687227\",\"isComplete\":true,\"genreNames\":[\"Alternative\",\"Music\"],\"trackCount\":12,\"isMasteredForItunes\":true,\"releaseDate\":\"2021-05-28\",\"name\":\"life's a beach\",\"artistUrl\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/easy-life/1362698163\",\"recordLabel\":\"Universal-Island Records Ltd.\",\"editorialArtwork\":{\"storeFlowcase\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/f0/bc/f3/f0bcf3cd-0a59-01dc-745a-42f65838e975/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"7b9fd7\",\"textColor1\":\"050304\",\"textColor2\":\"161b4e\",\"textColor3\":\"1c222e\",\"textColor4\":\"2a356a\"},\"subscriptionHero\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is1-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/d4/16/76/d416766a-ba50-359d-795d-b52041814554/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"503b65\",\"textColor1\":\"f5ddbe\",\"textColor2\":\"b0adfc\",\"textColor3\":\"d1b9ab\",\"textColor4\":\"9b94db\"}},\"upc\":\"00602435570365\",\"copyright\":\"An Island Records release; ? 2021 Universal Music Operations Limited\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1556687227\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"On their debut album, \u003ci\u003elife’s a beach\u003c/i\u003e, easy life takes us on a trip to the glorious British seaside. “Being from Leicester, we’re really, really far from the beach,” frontman Murray Matravers tells Apple Music. “This album was about dreaming big and trying to get out of your head. It was about the idea that surely life can be better than this.” Largely written during the UK’s first 2020 lockdown (but decidedly not a quarantine project), \u003ci\u003elife’s a beach\u003c/i\u003e is an album of two halves. You’ll find easy life’s reliably jovial sing-along anthems—which borrow from R\u0026B, hip-hop, jazz, pop, and even musical theater—on the first, from the wonky, affirming “message to myself” to the shoulder-shaking “skeletons.” Then, still grounded by Matravers’ loose, Jamie T-meets-Mike Skinner speak-singing, \u003ci\u003elife’s a beach\u003c/i\u003e moves into murkier waters. “This album starts like, ‘We’re going to have a great time at the beach and everything is going to be good!’” says Matravers. “Then it slowly gets worse and worse.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\nHere he explores his darkest moments with remarkable candor (see the propulsive, chaotic “living strange” and sad banger “nightmares”), as well as the people who’ve helped him out of them (“lifeboat”). But as the five-piece, completed by Oliver Cassidy, Sam Hewitt, Lewis Berry, and Jordan Birtles, calls it a night on the mashed “music to walk home to,” easy life reminds us what they have always been: a band that revels—and excels—in having fun. “We deal with some quite serious themes throughout the album and we have a place to talk about important shit, but I definitely don’t want anyone thinking we’re seriously deep,” adds Matravers. Read on as the frontman takes us on a track-by-track tour of easy life’s whirlwind debut.\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“a message to myself”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This was a real labor of love. I wrote my little bit in about 20 minutes, and it was pretty close to a freestyle. The instrumental came from [US producer] Bekon, who worked on the Kendrick Lamar \u003ci\u003eDAMN.\u003c/i\u003e album. We reached out to him in 2016 and he sent us this beat tape. We were tiny at the time, and Kendrick Lamar was Kendrick Lamar. I've never heard anything like it. As the album developed, I always thought it would be a really weird intro. This track was very much me reassuring myself. Like, ‘Hey, be yourself, because you've got to be authentic in this album, otherwise people won't dig it.’”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“have a great day”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This was written with [US producer] Gianluca Buccellati, two or three days before we went into the first lockdown in 2020, so it has a special place in my heart. We had the instrumental cooking up and it just felt like a breezy ’60s crooner-type song. It's about a trip to the beach. Again, like lots of our songs, it started as a bit of a joke and then it turned into something a lot more serious.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“ocean view”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I wrote this one with [US songwriter and producer] Rob Milton. Rob found the track ‘Loved the Ocean’ by [American singer-songwriter] Emilia Ali. If you’ve heard it, you’ll appreciate that we literally just took her entire song, sped it up a fraction, and pitched it up—a process that takes about five minutes—put some drums on, and then sang her chorus, which was already written. We basically plagiarized it. ‘ocean view’ is another track where you've gone to the seaside, but this is where the album starts looking a little less hopeful. We sent it to Emilia and she was stoked. She thinks it's cool.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“skeletons”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“‘ocean view’ and ‘skeletons’ are so different. We asked the mastering engineer to put the littlest space possible between the songs, because I thought it was cool to smash them together. It’s part of the journey of \u003ci\u003elife's a beach\u003c/i\u003e—now we’re into a different vibe entirely. It’s one of the only moments in the album where it's just a party. This song is about having skeletons in your closet. You meet someone and you know that they’re no good for you, but in a way that's quite alluring. I think we all fall into that trap. I certainly used to basically every single weekend.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“daydreams”\u003c/b\u003e \\n“I wrote this during lockdown. I think everyone can relate to it. It’s like, ‘Let's just get drunk and stoned and hopefully it will get slightly less boring but it's probably still quite boring.’ It’s about missing people as well. I spun it romantically, but it spans across friendships and family.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“life’s a beach (interlude)”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“We had a million interludes to choose from. We chose this one because it was in the right key after coming out of ‘daydreams’ and going into ‘living strange.’ It was a nice way of getting from A to B.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“living strange”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This is an old one. I wrote this one with my older brother. We're super close and we can talk about anything, so when we write music, it usually gets dark, because I'll be like, ‘All this shit's going down, it's terrible,’ and he’ll say, ‘Okay, let's write a song about it.’ Things were not good back then. I’ve come out of it now, but back then it was a bit of a whirlwind, and my brother was able to capture it perfectly. This is the first vocal take. I couldn’t recreate it—there’s a paranoia that seeps out. This album needed something on that self-destructive, end-of-the-world-type shit.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“compliments”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This was made with [Leeds-based producer and mixer] Lee Smith. I introduced him to Rob [Milton]. One time we were in a room and Lee was like, ‘You guys are just killing it,’ and Rob and I found it so awkward. It's hard to take a compliment. We wrote this song straight afterwards. It’s uplifting and positive, especially with the chords being so melodic and pretty. But there’s also an element of severed relationships and not speaking.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“lifeboat”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“So obviously we're into the second half of the album where shit's starting to go south. The lifeboat is a metaphor of someone who has helped you out of a bad patch. There are countless people who have helped me. This song was just me tipping my metaphorical hat to them. Musically, I wanted it to be super ’70s and slick and almost cheesy. In the way that Outkast might do something super cheesy, but it’s just cool as fuck. It was like I was trying to do our best André 3000 impression.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“nightmares”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I always think most of our music sounds pretty happy. But most of the stuff that provokes me to write is pretty sad. I’ve always seen ‘nightmares’ as hiding in plain sight. Sure, the music sounds anthemic, but I actually think this is our saddest song. This is obviously intentionally opposite to ‘daydreams.’ You daydream at the start of the album, but you end up in a nightmare.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“homesickness”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This is a pretty surface-level song. We were spending loads of time in America. Looking back, I wish I was really stoked about it because it was so much fun. But I spent most of the time missing home. It started with an arpeggiated chord that runs throughout the track. I remember being in the studio and that genuinely bringing a tear to my eye when we first heard it.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“music to walk home to”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“We collaborated with [British songwriter and producer] Fraser T. Smith on this record. We were hanging out at his studio writing stuff and got really drunk. Like, \u003ci\u003ereally\u003c/i\u003e drunk. We were listening to a lot of Fela Kuti at the time, and we just started making an instrumental. I’d written rough points about what it would be like to walk from the station to my house and the places I'd cross. I got a mic and did it in one take, at around one or two in the morning. I fluffed loads of the words because I was a bit steaming, but kept all of that in. I fell in love with the song after it was born. I just thought it was hilarious. It made sense to be the last track—you’ve gone away on this elaborate trip of self-discovery and now it’s time to go back to the flat and take stock and start over again. It was important to include one track that was purely a laugh.”\",\"short\":\"“Our music sounds happy, but the stuff that provokes it is pretty sad.”\"},\"isCompilation\":false,\"contentRating\":\"explicit\"},\"relationships\":{\"artists\":{\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1556687227/artists?l=en-US\",\"data\":[{\"id\":\"1362698163\",\"type\":\"artists\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/artists/1362698163?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"name\":\"easy 2021 Regent Park Songs\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1557495549\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"Over the past decade, Toronto’s Mustafa Ahmed has worn many hats: spoken-word poet, community activist, documentarian, member of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s policy-shaping Youth Advisory Council, and, more recently, a songwriter for pop stars like The Weeknd and Shawn Mendes. All of those accomplishments—not to mention a number of enthusiastic Drake endorsements—have made the long-awaited arrival of Mustafa’s debut release, \u003ci\u003eWhen Smoke Rises\u003c/i\u003e, a major event, complete with an A-list guest list that includes James Blake, Sampha, and Jamie xx. But Mustafa has answered those heightened expectations with a set of deeply meditative acoustic-soul hymns that, at times, feel almost too personal and painful to bear.\u003cbr /\u003e\\nThe title and cover shot of \u003ci\u003eWhen Smoke Rises\u003c/i\u003e pay tribute to Toronto MC Smoke Dawg, a fellow member of the Halal Gang rap collective who was killed in 2018, and these eight songs reverberate with the trauma of losing loved ones too soon and the crises of faith that result from enduring endless violence. Atop the rumbling rhythms of “The Hearse,” Mustafa preps his slain friend’s body for a traditional Muslim funeral while questioning whether his natural peacemaker instincts can keep his desire for vengeance at bay. “Ali” is even more harrowing, an emotional plea for a friend to leave town to avoid the trouble coming to him, only for the trouble to find him anyway. (“There were no words to stop the bullets,” Mustafa ruefully admits, in a voice that isn’t so much calm as numbed.) But \u003ci\u003eWhen Smoke Rises\u003c/i\u003e’ grim subtext is leavened by Mustafa’s natural melodic graces—even when recounting the worst days of his life, his songs summon the strength to carry on. “Just put down that bottle, tell me your sorrows,” he sings on the quiet yet resounding mission statement “Stay Alive,” a reminder that reckoning with the pain is the first step toward healing it.\",\"short\":\"The poet-songwriter debuts with a set of aching acoustic-soul hymns.\"},\"isCompilation\":false,\"contentRating\":\"explicit\"},\"relationships\":{\"artists\":{\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1557495549/artists?l=en-US\",\"data\":[{\"id\":\"1501533511\",\"type\":\"artists\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/artists/1501533511?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"name\":\"Mustafa\",\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/mustafa/1501533511\",\"artwork\":{\"width\":1317,\"height\":1317,\"url\":\"https://is2-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features124/v4/83/72/20/837220c9-c89c-19c3-ced2-fc6ba6c65b69/pr_source.png/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"91b3b5\",\"textColor1\":\"090c13\",\"textColor2\":\"172020\",\"textColor3\":\"242d34\",\"textColor4\":\"2f3d3e\"},\"editorialArtwork\":{}}}]}}},{\"id\":\"1567421945\",\"type\":\"albums\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1567421945?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"artwork\":{\"width\":5100,\"height\":5100,\"url\":\"https://is4-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Music125/v4/61/6d/2a/616d2a5d-98c2-de1d-7e06-502203554095/21UMGIM41232.rgb.jpg/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"1b1e2d\",\"textColor1\":\"95b2dc\",\"textColor2\":\"9baad0\",\"textColor3\":\"7d94b9\",\"textColor4\":\"818eaf\"},\"artistName\":\"J. Cole\",\"isSingle\":false,\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/album/the-off-season/1567421945\",\"isComplete\":true,\"genreNames\":[\"Hip-Hop/Rap\",\"Music\"],\"trackCount\":12,\"isMasteredForItunes\":true,\"releaseDate\":\"2021-05-14\",\"name\":\"The Off-Season\",\"artistUrl\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/j-cole/73705833\",\"recordLabel\":\"Dreamville, Inc., Under exclusive license to Roc Nation Records\",\"editorialArtwork\":{\"storeFlowcase\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/94/99/fa/9499fa2d-9860-a736-4f32-ff0c6de1ad75/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"46546d\",\"textColor1\":\"ffffff\",\"textColor2\":\"eab66e\",\"textColor3\":\"dadce1\",\"textColor4\":\"c9a26e\"},\"subscriptionHero\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is3-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/40/f3/d2/40f3d2eb-2dd4-0b49-0ce7-d07663220504/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"e6eadf\",\"textColor1\":\"272417\",\"textColor2\":\"252822\",\"textColor3\":\"4d4b3f\",\"textColor4\":\"4b4f48\"},\"staticDetailSquare\":{\"width\":3840,\"height\":3840,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/3d/01/f6/3d01f612-cb1a-2c4f-0e89-19cf5f43a7b7/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"111117\",\"textColor1\":\"8fa2d3\",\"textColor2\":\"778ecb\",\"textColor3\":\"7280a7\",\"textColor4\":\"5f71a0\"}},\"upc\":\"00810061165132\",\"copyright\":\"? 2021 Dreamville, Inc., Under exclusive license to Roc Nation Records\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1567421945\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"For athletes of both the professional and amateur ranks, the time between seasons is an opportunity to recuperate and to sharpen their tool set for the next run. Superstar MC J. Cole, whose career has long been informed by both basketball metaphor and actual basketball playing (in May 2021, ESPN reported that Cole had joined the Basketball Africa League's Rwanda Patriots BBC), has crafted his \u003ci\u003eThe Off-Season\u003c/i\u003e mixtape in the same mold, affirming that if he’s done anything in the time since 2018’s \u003ci\u003eKOD\u003c/i\u003e album, it’s get even better at what he does.\u003cbr /\u003e\\nThe 12-track tape is at once a testament to his actual rhyme skill and the reverence he’s earned within hip-hop. He’s sourced production from Boi-1da, Timbaland, Jake One, and T-Minus, among others, and has words—but not verses—from Cam’ron, Damian Lillard, and a man he admits to having once had an actual physical alteration with, Sean “Puff Daddy” Combs. Though he takes time to shout out both Chief Keef and Dave East—conspicuously opposite forces in the realm of contemporary rap—proper features here come from fellow Fayetteville native Morray and “a lot” collaborator 21 Savage. Over the course of his career, Cole’s been known as something of a lone wolf—J CoLe wEnT pLaTiNuM WiTh nO fEaTuReS. But in the scope of the energy we get from him on \u003ci\u003eThe Off-Season\u003c/i\u003e, it’s less likely that he’s been avoiding other rappers than that he's just left them all behind.\",\"short\":\"One of rap’s most beloved MCs refuses to be outworked.\"},\"isCompilation\":false,\"contentRating\":\"explicit\"},\"relationships\":{\"artists\":{\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1567421945/artists?l=en-US\",\"data\":[{\"id\":\"73705833\",\"type\":\"artists\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/artists/73705833?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"name\":\"J. {\"id\":\"1561836997\",\"type\":\"albums\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1561836997?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"artwork\":{\"width\":1425,\"height\":1425,\"url\":\"https://is3-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Music114/v4/64/82/1d/64821d19-14b2-7f58-8106-bccb4d04ada3/075679786210.jpg/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"7dc0c9\",\"textColor1\":\"191716\",\"textColor2\":\"222220\",\"textColor3\":\"2d3939\",\"textColor4\":\"344142\"},\"artistName\":\"twenty one pilots\",\"isSingle\":false,\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/album/scaled-and-icy/1561836997\",\"isComplete\":true,\"genreNames\":[\"Alternative\",\"Music\"],\"trackCount\":11,\"isMasteredForItunes\":true,\"releaseDate\":\"2021-05-21\",\"name\":\"Scaled And Icy\",\"artistUrl\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/twenty-one-pilots/349736311\",\"recordLabel\":\"Fueled By Ramen\",\"editorialArtwork\":{\"storeFlowcase\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is4-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features114/v4/31/93/5c/31935c43-3673-84ec-d83e-13a6d9ede1a5/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"f0eee4\",\"textColor1\":\"0a0c0b\",\"textColor2\":\"0c0c0c\",\"textColor3\":\"2b2c2a\",\"textColor4\":\"2c2c2c\"},\"subscriptionHero\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is2-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/07/03/bb/0703bbb1-c33c-6254-d4b3-f99315bd4a60/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"e698ae\",\"textColor1\":\"181818\",\"textColor2\":\"1c1b1a\",\"textColor3\":\"382d30\",\"textColor4\":\"3c3032\"},\"staticDetailSquare\":{\"width\":3840,\"height\":3840,\"url\":\"https://is2-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/2b/fb/e9/2bfbe931-482f-bade-64f4-c3306b53c30f/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"000000\",\"textColor1\":\"ffffff\",\"textColor2\":\"0a0a0b\",\"textColor3\":\"191e20\",\"textColor4\":\"181e20\"}},\"upc\":\"075679786210\",\"copyright\":\"? 2021 Fueled By Ramen LLC\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1561836997\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"The title of twenty one pilots’ sixth LP is a play on “scaled back and isolated,” words that summed up frontman Tyler Joseph’s world as he wrote and recorded in his Ohio basement during lockdown. “It just felt very confined,” he tells Apple Music. “I had this little dragon figurine that I kept on my desk during the entirety of the writing process, and I just knew that when you focus on even the tiniest little detail in your room—or wherever you're confined—that thing can come to life and fly around your room. That dragon on the cover really represents what can be accomplished with that sort of imagination.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\nAnd as has been the case for everyone, the challenges of pandemic living had a noticeable impact on Joseph’s work—but maybe not quite how you’d expect. “I was actively trying to push against that natural inclination to come in darker,” he says. “The idea of adding to the pressure of what's going on in our world, it didn't feel right.” Instead, \u003ci\u003eScaled and Icy\u003c/i\u003e finds Joseph pushing his genre-defying alt-pop into brighter, more hopeful territory. “It felt like I needed to go the opposite direction,” he says. “I wanted to escape a little bit more and provide people with that opportunity to escape too.” Here, Joseph takes us inside some of the album’s key tracks.\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Good Day”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I designed it to feel like something was coming to life. If you really listen to the song, it's so upbeat and shiny on the surface, and then lyrically I'm talking about trying to cope with the idea of if I were to ever lose my family and friends. I would probably go through a period in the mourning process where my reaction to anyone asking me how I'm doing would be like, ‘I'm fine. Everything's great, I don't even know why you're asking me.’ Making them feel stupid, like, ‘Why would you even ask me that?’ That's what this song is.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Choker”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I come from a basketball background, and choking is: You’re standing at the free-throw line and you need to make one of those two, and if you miss them both, you choked. I think for me, with certain friendships and relationships, there were moments that I could have risen to the occasion and I didn't, and that's something that I'll have to live with. I think that everyone has those moments where they feel like they choked. The song is trying to work that through and trying to figure out if that’s someone that I was born to be. Can I shape this? Is this something I can turn around?”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Shy Away”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“My brother said, ‘Hey, I just want you to show me, from the beginning, how you start a record. How do you start writing a song?’ So I had him over at the studio. A lot of times when I sit down to start, I'll tap into my phone and I’ll have a bunch of voice memos of ideas that have hit me randomly. Sometimes it’s just a single word, sometimes it's a melody. I started to build up the track from there, and it turned out that it was talking about wanting him to pursue his dream of chasing music. Most of my songs are very inward, but this is one of the few that I feel like the message is outward, coming from me. The only thing harder than figuring out what your purpose and identity is, is watching someone that you love trying to figure out theirs.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Saturday”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“When you strip away what day of the week it is, you lose your rhythm. You lose your sense of what is up and what is down. And that's a lesson that [drummer] Josh [Dun] and I learned pretty quickly on tour, because a Friday night and a Monday night could feel the exact same, whether or not we had a show. When the pandemic happened, everything's shut down, everyone was starting to learn that same lesson, where the days of the week lose their meaning, and it was messing with people's reference of time. You feel like you're swirling and your feet aren't planted. The song is really, I'm talking to my wife, hoping that she sticks with me, even though I'm working through this, even though I'm kind of tumbling into nothingness.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“No Chances”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I recruited my brother and a few of his friends to come over and record gang vocals. You have this microphone in the middle of the room and I have everyone in headphones and I'm kind of directing them in what to say and what to yell. That was the first time I'd ever really produced a room full of people. I was thinking of athletics and college sports specifically, where there's overwhelmingly this hometown crowd, and how intimidating that can be and powerful that is in the face of opposition. I definitely was writing from that—I felt the energy of a gymnasium or a stadium and was wanting to capture that.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Redecorate”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I had a friend of mine whose son passed away and they would keep his room the same way that he had left it. I remember thinking how crazy powerful a story that is, and how it makes me wonder, like, ‘What will people do with my stuff?’ It can actually bring you back down to earth, make sure that you don't make any horrible decisions. I'm realizing now how difficult it is to talk about, but this song is really important to me. I love the messaging of it, and I hope that our fans hear what it is I'm trying to say in it. Because it is a bit delicate, but it's one of my favorite tracks and it's pretty powerful if you let it.”\",\"short\":\"“I wanted to provide people with that opportunity to escape.”\"},\"isCompilation\":false},\"relationships\":{\"artists\":{\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1561836997/artists?l=en-US\",\"data\":[{\"id\":\"349736311\",\"type\":\"artists\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/artists/349736311?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"name\":\"twenty d3916\",\"textColor1\":\"f1d67b\",\"textColor2\":\"e8a65b\",\"textColor3\":\"cab667\",\"textColor4\":\"c3904d\"},\"artistName\":\"Mdou Moctar\",\"isSingle\":false,\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/album/afrique-victime/1552672500\",\"isComplete\":true,\"genreNames\":[\"Rock\",\"Music\"],\"trackCount\":9,\"isMasteredForItunes\":true,\"releaseDate\":\"2021-05-21\",\"name\":\"Afrique Victime\",\"artistUrl\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/mdou-moctar/552742374\",\"recordLabel\":\"Matador\",\"editorialArtwork\":{\"storeFlowcase\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is1-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/06/0c/7a/060c7a0a-6866-c485-c074-7d66ba141103/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"4a542f\",\"textColor1\":\"eef4ab\",\"textColor2\":\"9edb7a\",\"textColor3\":\"cdd492\",\"textColor4\":\"8dbf6b\"},\"subscriptionHero\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is3-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features124/v4/10/d2/ec/10d2ec3d-8c65-436e-a8a6-5d92a0baa511/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"0f0f0f\",\"textColor1\":\"dadcda\",\"textColor2\":\"c0c0c0\",\"textColor3\":\"a9aba9\",\"textColor4\":\"969696\"},\"staticDetailSquare\":{\"width\":3840,\"height\":3840,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/e1/43/3f/e1433f1d-519f-6c4f-3669-a07d2c354201/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"313d19\",\"textColor1\":\"f4e748\",\"textColor2\":\"becff4\",\"textColor3\":\"c7c13e\",\"textColor4\":\"9fafc0\"},\"staticDetailTall\":{\"width\":2048,\"url\":\"https://is3-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/4e/03/a5/4e03a5c0-c9b1-eac7-6db8-608f64d3a899/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"textGradient\":[\"ffffff\",\"ffffff\"],\"height\":2732,\"textColor3\":\"c7b345\",\"textColor2\":\"ffffff\",\"textColor4\":\"41cf50\",\"textColor1\":\"ffffff\",\"bgColor\":\"303c19\"}},\"upc\":\"191401161459\",\"copyright\":\"? 2021 Matador\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1552672500\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"In his native country of Niger, singer-songwriter Mdou Moctar taught himself to play guitar by watching videos of Eddie Van Halen’s iconic shredding. When you hear his unique psych-rock hybrid—a mix of traditional Tuareg melodies with the kinds of buzzing strings and trilling fret runs that people often associate with the recently deceased guitar god—it makes sense. Moctar has honed that stylistic fingerprint over the course of five albums, after first being introduced to Western audiences via Sahel Sounds’ now cult classic compilation \u003ci\u003eMusic From Saharan Cellphones, Vol. 1\u003c/i\u003e, and in the process has been heartily embraced by indie rock fans based on his sound alone (he also plays on Bonnie \\\"Prince” Billy and Matt Sweeney’s \u003ci\u003eSuperwolves\u003c/i\u003e album).\u003cbr /\u003e\\nThe songs that make up \u003ci\u003eAfrique Victime\u003c/i\u003e alternate between jubilant, sometimes meandering and jammy (the opening “Chismiten”)—mirroring his band’s explosive live shows—and more tightly wound, raga-like and reflective (the trance-inducing “Ya Habibti”). But within the music, there’s a deeper, often political context: Recorded with his group in studios, apartments, hotel rooms, backstage, and outdoors, the album covers a range of themes: love, religion, women’s rights, inequality, and the exploitation of West Africa by colonial powers. “I felt like giving a voice to all those who suffer on my continent and who are ignored by the Western world,” Moctar tells Apple Music. Here he dissects each of the album’s tracks.\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Chismiten”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“The song talks about jealousy in a relationship, but more importantly about making sure that you’re not swept away too quickly by this emotion, which I think can be very harmful. Every individual, man or woman, has the right to have relationships outside marriage, be it with friends or family.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Taliat”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“It’s another song that addresses relationships, the suffering we go through when we’re deeply in love with someone who doesn’t return that love.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Ya Habibti”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“The title of this track, which I composed a long time ago, means ‘oh my love’ in Arabic. I reminisce about that evening in August when I met my wife and how I immediately thought she was so beautiful.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Tala Tannam”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This is also a song I wrote for my wife when I was far away from her, on a trip. I tell her that wherever I may be, I’ll be thinking of her.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Asdikte Akal”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“It’s about my origins and the sense of nostalgia I feel when I think about the village where I grew up, about my country and all those I miss when I’m far away from them, like my mother and my brothers.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Layla”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Layla is my wife. When she gave birth to our son, I wasn’t allowed to be by her side, because that’s just how it is for men in our country. I was on tour when she called me, very worried, to tell me that our son was about to be born. I felt really helpless, and as a way of offering comfort, I wrote this song for her.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Afrique Victime”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Although my country gained its independence a long time ago, France had promised to help us, but we never received that support. Most of the people in Niger don’t have electricity or drinking water. That’s what I emphasize in this song.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Bismilahi Atagah”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This one talks about the various possible dangers that await us, about everything that could make us turn our back on who we really are, such as the illusion of love and the lure of money.”\",\"short\":\"“I felt like giving a voice to all those who suffer.”\"},\"isCompilation\":false},\"relationships\":{\"artists\":{\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1552672500/artists?l=en-US\",\"data\":[{\"id\":\"552742374\",\"type\":\"artists\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/artists/552742374?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"name\":\"Mdou Moctar\",\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/mdou-moctar/552742374\",\"artwork\":{\"width\":2400,\"height\":2400,\"url\":\"https://is2-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features114/v4/91/6e/cf/916ecfa6-ec86-576d-35b6-96366167978c/pr_source.png/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"f5f5f3\",\"textColor1\":\"06090a\",\"textColor2\":\"3d3124\",\"textColor3\":\"363839\",\"textColor4\":\"61584e\"},\"editorialArtwork\":{}}}]}}},{\"id\":\"1568588941\",\"type\":\"albums\",\"href\":\"/v1/catalog/us/albums/1568588941?l=en-US\",\"attributes\":{\"artwork\":{\"width\":1425,\"height\":1425,\"url\":\"https://is5-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Music115/v4/e3/d2/2e/e3d22ecc-9594-8b92-6606-1f39708b89c9/075679786920.jpg/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"0e0e18\",\"textColor1\":\"ebe5e1\",\"textColor2\":\"99b4c9\",\"textColor3\":\"bebab8\",\"textColor4\":\"7d92a5\"},\"artistName\":\"Pooh Shiesty\",\"isSingle\":false,\"url\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/album/shiesty-season-spring-deluxe/1568588941\",\"isComplete\":true,\"genreNames\":[\"Hip-Hop/Rap\",\"Music\"],\"trackCount\":21,\"isMasteredForItunes\":false,\"releaseDate\":\"2021-05-21\",\"name\":\"Shiesty Season - Spring Deluxe\",\"artistUrl\":\"https://music.apple.com/us/artist/pooh-shiesty/1456620250\",\"recordLabel\":\"Atlantic Records\",\"editorialArtwork\":{\"storeFlowcase\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is4-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/9c/e4/f5/9ce4f576-7951-df96-e255-8f6fb1f05fce/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"000000\",\"textColor1\":\"df926d\",\"textColor2\":\"d68b65\",\"textColor3\":\"b37557\",\"textColor4\":\"ab6f51\"},\"subscriptionHero\":{\"width\":4320,\"height\":1080,\"url\":\"https://is1-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/08/cc/89/08cc89c8-a850-ade3-9d81-a8f98067e3b9/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"000000\",\"textColor1\":\"f6a17d\",\"textColor2\":\"eb9266\",\"textColor3\":\"c58164\",\"textColor4\":\"bc7551\"},\"staticDetailSquare\":{\"width\":3840,\"height\":3840,\"url\":\"https://is4-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features115/v4/8f/96/cb/8f96cb12-24e2-97e6-8b19-4c97f9bd5512/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"bgColor\":\"12181a\",\"textColor1\":\"c5b409\",\"textColor2\":\"d36e8d\",\"textColor3\":\"9b900b\",\"textColor4\":\"a55b73\"},\"staticDetailTall\":{\"width\":2048,\"url\":\"https://is1-ssl.mzstatic.com/image/thumb/Features125/v4/7d/c4/9f/7dc49f37-9420-d479-4998-356604303b1b/source/{w}x{h}bb.{f}\",\"textGradient\":[\"ffffff\",\"ffffff\"],\"height\":2732,\"textColor3\":\"a1930d\",\"textColor2\":\"ffffff\",\"textColor4\":\"9a7528\",\"textColor1\":\"ffffff\",\"bgColor\":\"0f1a1e\"}},\"upc\":\"075679786920\",\"copyright\":\"? 2021 Atlantic Recording Corporation and 1017 Global Music, LLC.\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1568588941\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"The most accurate distillation of Pooh Shiesty’s mission on debut mixtape \u003ci\u003eShiesty Season\u003c/i\u003e comes from one of the project’s guests. “I don’t wanna rap about nothing but gunplay,” 21 Savage deadpans on “Box of Churches.” Savage appears on the tape alongside fellow street-rap heavyweights Gucci Mane and Lil Durk, as well as a handful of lesser-known MCs like BIG30, Choppa Wop, and Lil Hank. If they have a single thing in common, it’s an affinity for high-powered weaponry. But it is Pooh Shiesty, of course, who set the tone.\u003cbr /\u003e\\nAcross \u003ci\u003eShiesty Season - Spring Deluxe\u003c/i\u003e’s 21 tracks, the MC consistently details, in that readily identifiable Memphis drawl, the importance of guns in his life on songs like “Back in Blood,” “50 Shots,” “Take a Life,” and “Choppa Way.” Deviations from the theme are few and far between, even on songs like the one named for pioneering musical entrepreneur and Dirty South hip-hop legend Master P (“One shot to the head, may he rest in peace/I’m the reason doctors hooked him up, I feel like Master P”). And lest you think a song called “Twerksum” was an attempt at appeasing the fairer sex, Shiesty is simply offering fair warning that the “choppa get to shaking like it twerk or something.”\",\"short\":\"Featuring four new tracks, including “Welcome to the Riches” with Lil 2021 Ten Point Productions, Inc. under exclusive license to Warner Records Inc.\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1563077926\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"“The truth is I love country music, and I love a great country lyric and a great country melody, and I just want to record a bunch of those songs,” Blake Shelton tells Apple Music. “That's as honest as I can be with you about it.” Shelton makes good on that love for narrative-driven, melodic country music with \u003ci\u003eBody Language\u003c/i\u003e, his 12th studio album and the follow-up to 2017’s \u003ci\u003eTexoma Shore\u003c/i\u003e. The album opens with “Minimum Wage,” a piano-driven anthem about the kind of love that transcends money. “Corn” is a foot-stomping ode to Shelton’s favorite grain, with an appropriately twang-heavy arrangement. And closer “Bible Verses” shows off Shelton’s serious side with a meditation on spirituality and grace. Shelton tapped longtime producer Scott Hendricks to helm the LP, as well as his fiancée, Gwen Stefani, who joins him on “Happy Anywhere.” Below, Shelton shares insight into several of \u003ci\u003eBody Language\u003c/i\u003e’s tracks.\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Minimum Wage”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“The number one reason I recorded that song is because I thought how fun it would be to do it live. And one step beyond that is I thought it would be a great show opener, because it's got that super long intro that builds. I was like, ‘Oh my god, I can see some fog on the stage, and I come up on one of those stupid elevators, or whatever.’ You have all these little images in your mind of how you're going to do it.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Body Language”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“For eight years now, since I met The Swon Brothers, we've had this relationship, and they finally sent a song over that was like, ‘Well, I don't think you should put that on your EP, because I actually want that one.’ They had sent it just trying to get feedback, and I was like, ‘Hey, well, tell them the feedback is that I want that thing.’ I really just tried to do the best I could at making my version of that song sound just like what they had created, because they really nailed the track. But they're actually on the record singing all the background, and I wanted it to not just be a cut for them. I wanted to feature them on the record, too. And hopefully they get even more mileage out of that, also.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Corn”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I'm in a situation with Craig Wiseman where the record label knows, ‘I don't care what you guys think of it, if Craig Wiseman writes a song and sends it, just send it to me.’ Mostly because I just love to hear his voice on demos. I mean, you know when it's a Craig Wiseman song. I don't know what's going on with him vocally, but it's weird and I love it. But he sent me that song directly because he knows that literally corn is my life. I mean, I eat it, I plant it, I feed it to deer, everything around me is corn. I'm a corny person, I guess.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Bible Verses”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“That song is so honest and so intense, and so personal in ways when you sing it, because you're going, ‘Oh my god, I'm telling everybody that I'm really not always everything I want to be.’ But I think, if we're being honest as recording artists, as human beings, you got to go there. Sometimes I just feel like I'm never going to measure up to what God expects me to be. And I think we all probably have that moment every now and then.”\",\"short\":\"“The truth is I love country music and I want to record a bunch of those 2021 CMG/N-Less/Interscope Records\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1562769837\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"When it’s all said and done, there’s no telling how COVID-19 will have affected the artistry of some of our favorite music-makers—except in the case of Moneybagg Yo, who tells Apple Music very plainly that it made him a more focused MC. “I just feel like a lot of my old music the fans didn't accept how I wanted them to accept it,” he says. “I just was in a different stage of my life and I was moving around a lot. The COVID situation had to happen, and by that happening, I sat down and thought about everything and I made the biggest songs of my career—of my life—in the pandemic.” \u003cbr /\u003e\\nHere, Yo might be referring to the lead single from his fourth album \u003ci\u003eA Gangsta’s Pain\u003c/i\u003e, the Future collaboration and instantaneous smash hit “Hard for the Next.” Or maybe he’s referring to an altogether trippy exploration of relationships through the eyes of a lean addict called “Wockesha.” Maybe he’s just that proud of the hard-charging “Shottas,” where he debuts a completely new flow. But regardless of which songs he’s referring to, the M-town representer claims that the break in action the world was forced to observe showed him exactly who he is. “I feel like by me sitting down and just figuring it out, I'm going to go back to the roots,” he says. “I'm giving them everything they love about Moneybagg Yo.” Below, the Memphis MC breaks down how we got the best of him on his favorite tracks from \u003ci\u003eA Gangsta’s Pain\u003c/i\u003e.\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Hard for the Next”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Me and Future, every time we get in the kitchen, the chemistry is always there, so I feel like this kind of happened naturally. When he gets you in there, he's going to lock you in and play all of what he's been working on. So, he played me everything and he kept skipping by stuff. I’m like, 'Bruh, go back! Go back to that. You're trying to hide this joint from me.' He was like, 'Nah, bruh, you can have whatever you want.' So my engineer got the session, I went back and recorded it, sent it to him, and the rest was history.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“GO!” feat. BIG30\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I felt like I got to do one of them songs on here to where like I'm just giving it to them. I'm just on it. I ain't let up off the beat, just tempo. I got to lace BIG30 up on it because that's my artist, I want to see him win.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Projects”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I was going through like, ‘What am I missing?’ And then I get the call that Pharrell wants to lock in for two days straight, so I was a little— you know how it be. Then, I came to the studio and I just laced it.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Certified Neptunes” feat. Pharrell Williams\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Pharrell had the chorus already laced up when I walked in. And then he was like, ‘Look, this is how I do it. My stuff, when I cook up, it be like a skit, so this is where I want to go with it. Just go in and then we're going to draw around it.’ It's like the trap energy, gutter-type Pharrell on that one.” \u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Change Da Subject”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“This the type of song, you go in the booth and you just close your eyes, and you think about everything. You think about everything like how it started, where you're trying to go, who you do it for; all your accomplishments. You probably heard me saying something like, 'No more pain and suffering.' It's a good feeling to be there.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Wockesha”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“‘Wockesha’ was just was like one of them songs like, you rap about your habits, you rap about what you got going on in your personal life. Because you know, sometimes when you're in a relationship with a girl and you got stuff going on, it's like you be back and forth: You can say, ‘It's not gon' be this,’ and it ends up being that again. It's like relapsing. And that's the same thing people do with drugs and other stuff. They'll say, 'I'm through doing this, I'm through doing that,' but then they'll get back on it. So, I just went off the concept of that. I'm just painting pictures.”\u003cbr /\u003e \\n\u003cb\u003e“One of Dem Nights”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“Jhené [Aiko] is one of my favorites. And then I was in the studio, the first beat that YC played, it was on point. I told him where I wanted to go, who I wanted to put on it. As soon as he went that way, it was crazy. I just started mumbling the words and I went in there and did it. I sent it to her, they sent it back. Real classic.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\n\u003cb\u003e“Shottas (Lala)”\u003c/b\u003e\\n“I was in the studio just joking around. It was me and the guys, we was just in there just kicking it and YC just comes in there playing beats. I was like, ‘Man, what the hell is this?’ This is one of them type of vibes you just—it don't matter what you say, just go in that joint and just say whatever comes to mind.”\",\"short\":\"“I'm giving 2021 !K7 Music\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1562174369\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"!K7’s long-running \u003ci\u003eDJ-Kicks\u003c/i\u003e mix series has generally been \u003ci\u003ethe\u003c/i\u003e place for established legends—or legends in the making—of dance music to show off their one-of-a-kind skills as technicians and selectors. Jayda G—the London-based Canadian producer/DJ born Jayda Guy—uses the platform to do both while drawing a line between the richly orchestrated disco-soul and jazz-funk of the ’80s and the sleek deep house of today. “I wanted to showcase my more eclectic electronic music side,” she tells Apple Music of her mix, which moves from rare gems such as Aged in Harmony’s “You’re a Melody” and Light of the World’s “London Town” to premiering a number of brand-new tracks like DJ BORING’s “Gardenia,” Fred again..’s “Diana (You Don't Even Know),” and LNS’s “Bitumen.” \\\"People may not hear those types of songs in my sets all the time, but they are tracks that I truly love,” she says of the dynamic tracklist. But whether it’s those languid songs that open or the more chugging percussion tunes that take it home, the through line here, not surprisingly, is a groove so wide and deep you could turn a cruise 2021 Nonesuch Records Inc.\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1562742266\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"If 2019’s \u003ci\u003e“Let’s Rock”\u003c/i\u003e allowed The Black Keys to go back to basics with their blues-smoked garage rock, then on \u003ci\u003eDelta Kream\u003c/i\u003e, they honor the source. “Any chance we get to turn people on hill country blues, we want to do that, because it means that much to us,” singer-songwriter-guitarist Dan Auerbach tells Apple Music. “We love this music and definitely feel a close connection to it.”\u003cbr /\u003e\\nRecorded during a two-day session in Nashville with local musicians Kenny Brown and Eric Deaton, the Nashville-by-way-of-Akron, Ohio duo’s 10th LP features reworkings of North Mississippi hill country blues standards they’ve been listening to since they were in their teens. Their passion for the genre shows in their raw and effortless performances—whether they turn John Lee Hooker’s “Crawling Kingsnake” into a six-minute incendiary jam or give the full treatment to R.L. Burnside’s “Mellow Peaches” with a soulful guitar interplay that rises into an intense crescendo. But for the most part, Auerbach and drummer Patrick Carney are not interested in adding any bells and whistles, like on “Sad Days, Lonely Nights,” where they capture the live essence of Junior Kimbrough’s 1994 original. “Some of the best roots music are those spontaneous records,” Auerbach adds. “You can just feel this kind of nervous energy, but it was just fun.”\",\"short\":\"“Any chance returns to his country roots on \u003ci\u003eCountry Again (Side A)\u003c/i\u003e, the first side of a planned double album. The 11 tracks, cowritten by Rhett, dig back into the sounds, emotions, and stories that initially inspired the superstar artist to pursue country music back when he was a wide-eyed teenager. But while the music may be a throwback, lyrically, \u003ci\u003eCountry Again\u003c/i\u003e reflects his growth as both a writer and a person, with “To the Guys That Date My Girls” addressing his role as a father and “Heaven Right Now” wrestling with the grief following the death of a friend. 2021 Republic Records, a division of UMG Recordings, Inc.\",\"playParams\":{\"id\":\"1567455268\",\"kind\":\"album\"},\"editorialNotes\":{\"standard\":\"One of the nicest things about Nicki Minaj bringing \u003ci\u003eBeam Me Up Scotty\u003c/i\u003e to streaming 12 years after its initial 2009 release—and with three new songs and two mid-career singles—is that fans get to see clearly both the evolution and consistency of the Queens rapper. The additions are tacked on to the top of her classic mixtape, thus beginning with her present and moving backwards towards her early days; what's revealed is a compelling ascent that looks entirely inevitable.\u003cbr /\u003e\\nOn “Seeing Green,” which opens the proceedings, she spars with her YMCMB family, proving that, as was the case then, she can not only effortlessly hang with some of the greatest, but bring the best out of them as well. “Fractions,” a la “Chi-Raq” just a couple songs later, is vintage Nicki—a showcase of hypnotic cadences and clever lyricism that never stops rewarding repeated listens.\u003cbr /\u003e\\nBut the real magic begins with the still-stunning “Itty Bitty Piggy.” Atop Soulja Boy's “Donk” beat, she lets loose a barrage of inventive wordplay (“Flyer than a kite, I get higher than Rapunzel/Keep the Snow White, I could buy it by the bundle,” she spits at one point), breathless flows, and undeniable charisma that, even a decade-plus on, cements that Nicki was always a star. Elsewhere, more playful songs like “Slumber Party” (with early cosigner Gucci Mane) and “I Get Crazy” (with Lil Wayne) and mellower ones like “Can Anybody Hear Me?” and “Still I Rise” testify to the vision of versatility she's always had: a riveting combination of pop theatrics and quick-witted rhymes all pulled together by a personality she's never been afraid to hide. \u003cbr /\u003e\\nA few of the original tracks are missing here—“Mind on My Money,” “Handstand,” and “I Feel Free” among them—but the spirit of \u003ci\u003eBeam Me Up Scotty\u003c/i\u003e, and the energy it brought to the rap landscape, remains fully intact. Much the way the tape doubled as Nicki’s claim to the throne in its time, in 2021, it's another excuse to adjust her crown.\",\"short\":\"The rapper’s classic mixtape arrives on streaming with some
